Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: First, I need to calculate the total duration for each case by finding the time difference between the first Submit Claim event and the last Close Claim event. Let me go through each case one by one.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Case 2003: - Submit 09:10 on 2024-04-01, Close 09:30 on 2024-04-03. Oh! That's two full days. Let me calculate properly: From 04-01 09:10 to 04-03 09:30 → 48 hours and 20 minutes. That's way longer than others. Case 2005: - Submit 09:25 on 04-01, Close 14:30 on 04-04. ... 04-01 09:25 to 04-04 14:30 → 3 days 5 hours 5 minutes. Super long.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: So Case 2003 and 2005 are clearly the outliers. Now I need to dig into why.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: For Case 2003: Complexity: High. After Evaluate Claim, they did two Request Additional Documents. For Case 2005: Complexity: High. Multiple Request Additional Documents ... three separate requests over 48 hours! Hmm... both high-complexity cases have multiple document requests.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: The pattern is clear: high complexity correlates with more document requests, which directly increases duration. But why are there multiple requests? Probably because the initial request wasn't sufficient, or the claimant didn't provide complete docs.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Looking at resources: ... So the resource isn't the issue ... Wait, let me double-check Region A vs B: ... So within each region, complexity drives duration.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: The root cause seems to be that high-complexity claims require multiple rounds of document requests because the initial request might be too vague... Best practice would be to list all missing documents in one request. So the root cause is poor initial assessment leading to fragmented requests.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: So to summarize: Slow cases: 2003 and 2005. Root cause: High complexity leading to multiple document requests (2 for 2003, 3 for 2005) due to insufficient initial request detail. Mitigation: Standardize document request templates for high-complexity claims to minimize back-and-forth.
